You're a Computer Athlete

entry.title: New Time Units for Higher Productivity (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Productivity

New Time Units for Higher Productivity

Our common measures of time never worked for me for time management. So I invented my own.

entry.title: The Input Channel Audit (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Attention Design

The Input Channel Audit

A quick How To guide for shaping your information diet

entry.title: Develop Strong Criteria for Input Triage (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Attention Design

Develop Strong Criteria for Input Triage

'How in the world. You need less Twitter in your life.' I had, again, discarded my guard rails of attention design and failed at input triage.

entry.title: The Seven Questions At The Heart Of Knowledge Ops (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Knowledge Ops

The Seven Questions At The Heart Of Knowledge Ops

Personal Knowledge Management is too restrictive â€“ you want to think about all seven of these questions instead.

entry.title: The Grazing â€“ Feeding Model of Information Gathering (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Knowledge Ops

The Grazing â€“ Feeding Model of Information Gathering

On the Internet, information is limitless. The Grazing-Feeding Model of Information Gathering helps you know how you're engaging with that information.

entry.title: Sadly, Constraints Are Real (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Constraints

Sadly, Constraints Are Real

For the last 15 years I've ignored one fundamental truth: real constraints exist. Here's what I'm trying now.

entry.title: Adversarial Reading (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Algorithm of Thought

Adversarial Reading

Bullshit is everywhere, and these algorithms of thought help you do more adversarial reading.

entry.title: How to improve a process (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Productivity

How to improve a process

With taking notes as an example, let's talk about how to improve any process.

entry.title: Don't Fiddle With Your Note-Taking System (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Note-taking

Don't Fiddle With Your Note-Taking System

You should stick to one note-taking system and fiddle with it as little as possible. That's a myth.

entry.title: Get Rid of Peer Review and Academic Journals (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Peer Review

Get Rid of Peer Review and Academic Journals

Why to get rid of peer review and academic journals as we know them â€“ and possibly what to do instead.

entry.title: You Actually Need to Context Switch (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Productivity

You Actually Need to Context Switch

Common wisdom says that you need to avoid context switching. That's only half true â€“ sometimes you need to context switch.

entry.title: How to Context Switch Like a Pro (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Productivity

How to Context Switch Like a Pro

Context switching is unavoidable â€“ but you can make it less costly by combining a couple of simple strategies.

entry.title: A Tale of Two Biases: How To Read The News (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Reading

A Tale of Two Biases: How To Read The News

Counter two frequent biases while reading the news: Selection Bias and Description Bias.

entry.title: How to use Roam Research for Interstitial Journaling (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Interstitial Journaling

How to use Roam Research for Interstitial Journaling

Interstitial Journaling is a great technique for minimizing context switching costs and staying productive. Here's how I use it in Roam Reserch.

entry.title: Why You Should Pick Zotero As A Reference Manager (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Academic Workflow

Why You Should Pick Zotero As A Reference Manager

A guide to reference managers, what you should expect from them and why Zotero is the reference manager you should use - whether you're in academia or not.

entry.title: Behavior First, Theory Second (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Learning

Behavior First, Theory Second

Behavior and Theory are two heuristics that can help you in deciding between courses and teachers.

entry.title: True Algorithms of Thought Have Arrived (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Algorithm of Thought

True Algorithms of Thought Have Arrived

Can you imagine being able to transfer 'mental software' between people? It's now possible, by using Algorithms of Thought in Roam Research.

entry.title: The Power of Keystone Habits with Roam Research (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Programming Attention

The Power of Keystone Habits with Roam Research

How to use Roam Research as your keystone habit to regularly revisit writing that is important to you, using the âˆ† feature in Roam.

entry.content:

entry.title: My grandfather's research technique - Index, Proto-Zettelkasten, Paper (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Zettelkasten

My grandfather's research technique - Index, Proto-Zettelkasten, Paper

My grandfather's way of doing history research before the computer age. Using paper and a meticulous process, he built something close to a Zettelkasten.

entry.title: How to cure Highlight Dementia (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Reading

How to cure Highlight Dementia

How to make sure that you never lose insights when reading and highlighting. Because Highlight Dementia is completely preventable.

entry.title: Actor's Concepts and Inventing Discovery (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Reading

Actor's Concepts and Inventing Discovery

How discovery became an actor's concept - and what you can use that for. Can you play chess without knowing that you are doing so?

entry.title: Getting Started with Algorithms of Thought (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Reading

Getting Started with Algorithms of Thought

An introduction to Algorithms of Thought - how they differ from Mental Models and how to use them in Roam Research.

entry.title: Universal-X - Of Polymaths and other fantastic creatures (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Polymathy

Universal-X - Of Polymaths and other fantastic creatures

There are words you can't use to describe yourself without sounding like an utter ass. Imagine asking someone at a party who they are and they respond with 'Nice to meet you, I'm a brilliant photographer/physicist/writer' - instant, life-long friends you'll be, no?

entry.title: The Right to Disagree (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Algorithm of Thought

The Right to Disagree

Contrary to popular belief, you can't just disagree with someone because you feel like it. You have to __earn__ the right to disagree with someone's position.

entry.title: Reply to: GOT1 constrains TH17 cell differentiation, while promoting iTreg cell differentiation (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Reply to: GOT1 constrains TH17 cell differentiation, while promoting iTreg cell differentiation

  • Tao Xu
  • Zhen Qin
  • Sheng Ding
Matters Arising 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: A high-mass X-ray binary descended from an ultra-stripped supernova (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
A high-mass X-ray binary descended from an ultra-stripped supernova

A recently discovered high-mass X-ray binary has an evolutionary history showing the neutron star component formed during an ultra-stripped supernova, and has orbital elements that should allow for forming a binary neutron star in the future.

  • Noel D. Richardson
  • Clarissa M. Pavao
  • Jeremy Hare
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Biomolecular analyses enable new insights into ancient Egyptian embalming (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Biomolecular analyses enable new insights into ancient Egyptian embalming

Philological analysis of labels and instructions, together with gas chromatographyâ€“mass spectrometry analysis of residues on vessels recovered from a 26th Dynasty embalming workshop at Saqqara, Egypt provide insights into ancient Egyptian embalming practices.

  • Maxime Rageot
  • Ramadan B. Hussein
  • Philipp W. Stockhammer
Article Open Access 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: mRNA ageing shapes the Cap2 methylome in mammalian mRNA (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
mRNA ageing shapes the Cap2 methylome in mammalian mRNA

Cap2 methylation increases on transcripts as they age, reducing activation of innate immunity.

  • Vladimir Despic
  • Samie R. Jaffrey
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Field-linked resonances of polar molecules (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Field-linked resonances of polar molecules

A type of universal scattering resonance between ultracold microwave-dressed polar molecules associated with field-linked tetramer bound states in the long-range potential well is observed, providing a general strategy for resonant scattering between ultracold polar molecules.

  • Xing-Yan Chen
  • Andreas Schindewolf
  • Xin-Yu Luo
Article Open Access 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Exceptional fossil preservation and evolution of the ray-finned fish brain (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Exceptional fossil preservation and evolution of the ray-finned fish brain

A well-preserved 319-million-year-old brain of the extinct vertebrate Coccocephalus wildi provides insights into neural anatomy deep within the phylogeny of ray-finned fish.

  • Rodrigo T. Figueroa
  • Danielle Goodvin
  • Sam Giles
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: GOT1 constrains TH17 cell differentiation, while promoting iTreg cell differentiation (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
GOT1 constrains TH17 cell differentiation, while promoting iTreg cell differentiation

  • Wei Xu
  • Chirag H. Patel
  • Jonathan D. Powell
Matters Arising 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: A Feshbach resonance in collisions between triplet ground-state molecules (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
A Feshbach resonance in collisions between triplet ground-state molecules

Observations of a pronounced and narrow Feshbach resonance in collisions between two triplet ground-state NaLi molecules are described, providing evidence for the existence of long-lived coherent intermediate complexes even in systems without reaction barriers.

  • Juliana J. Park
  • Yu-Kun Lu
  • Wolfgang Ketterle
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Reducing affinity as a strategy to boost immunomodulatory antibody agonism (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Reducing affinity as a strategy to boost immunomodulatory antibody agonism

In contrast to direct-targeting monoclonal antibodies, low affinity confers agonistic monoclonal antibodies with more potency.

  • Xiaojie Yu
  • Christian M. Orr
  • Mark S. Cragg
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Slow TCA flux and ATP production in primary solid tumours but not metastases (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Slow TCA flux and ATP production in primary solid tumours but not metastases

As solid tumours develop, cancer cells shed energetically expensive tissue-specific functions, enabling uncontrolled growth despite a limited ability to produce ATP.

  • Caroline R. Bartman
  • Daniel R. Weilandt
  • Joshua D. Rabinowitz
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Single-cell spatial immune landscapes of primary and metastatic brain tumours (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Single-cell spatial immune landscapes of primary and metastatic brain tumours

Imaging mass cytometry of human brain tumours provides spatial information that, combined with existing transcriptomic data, reveals the existence of a cellular neighbourhood containing a rare macrophage population associated with prolonged survival.

  • Elham Karimi
  • Miranda W. Yu
  • Logan A. Walsh
Article Open Access 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Probing site-resolved correlations in a spin system of ultracold molecules (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Probing site-resolved correlations in a spin system of ultracold molecules

Experiments demonstrate the powerful capabilities of ultracold molecules to study dynamics in the context of quantum magnetism, and create new possibilities for studying quantum physics with ultracold molecules more broadly.

  • Lysander Christakis
  • Jason S. Rosenberg
  • Waseem S. Bakr
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Measurement of the axial vector form factor from antineutrinoâ€“proton scattering (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Measurement of the axial vector form factor from antineutrinoâ€“proton scattering

The authors measure the nucleon axial vector form factor, which encodes information on the distribution of the nucleon weak charge, through antineutrinoâ€“proton scattering.

  • T. Cai
  • M. L. Moore
  • L. Zazueta
Article Open Access 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Vertical full-colour micro-LEDs via 2D materials-based layer transfer (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Vertical full-colour micro-LEDs via 2D materials-based layer transfer

We report full-colour, vertically stacked ÂµLEDs that achieve exceptionally high array density (5,100â€‰pixels per inch) and small size (4â€‰Âµm) via a 2D material-based layer transfer technique, allowing the creation of full-colour ÂµLED displays for augmented and virtual reality.

  • Jiho Shin
  • Hyunseok Kim
  • Jeehwan Kim
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Structural basis for substrate selection by the SARS-CoV-2 replicase (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Structural basis for substrate selection by the SARS-CoV-2 replicase

Cryo-EM is used to visualize the SARS-CoV-2 RTC bound to each of the natural NTPs as well as remdesivir triphosphate (RDV-TP) in states poised for incorporation, explaining the interactions required for NTP recognition and RDV-TP selectivity.

  • Brandon F. Malone
  • Jason K. Perry
  • Seth A. Darst
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Pseudospin-selective Floquet band engineering in black phosphorus (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Pseudospin-selective Floquet band engineering in black phosphorus

In black phosphorus, a model semiconductor, analysis of time and angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy measurements demonstrates a strong light-induced band renormalization with light polarization dependence, suggesting pseudospin-selective Floquet band engineering.

  • Shaohua Zhou
  • Changhua Bao
  • Shuyun Zhou
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Tunable itinerant spin dynamics with polar molecules (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Tunable itinerant spin dynamics with polar molecules

Tunable itinerant spin dynamics enabled by dipolar interactions are demonstrated with polar molecules, establishing an interacting spin platform that allows for exploration of many-body spin dynamics and spin-motion physics using strong, tunable dipolar interaction.

  • Jun-Ru Li
  • Kyle Matsuda
  • Jun Ye
Article 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Single-cell spatial landscapes of the lung tumour immune microenvironment (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Single-cell spatial landscapes of the lung tumour immune microenvironment

Using imaging mass cytometry, the tumour and immunological spatial landscapes of 416 lung adenocarcinomas are characterized, which, when combined with deep learning, can predict clinical outcomes with high accuracy.

  • Mark Sorin
  • Morteza Rezanejad
  • Logan A. Walsh
Article Open Access 01 Feb 2023

entry.title: Organic reaction mechanism classification using machine learning (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Organic reaction mechanism classification using machine learning

Mechanistic elucidation through currently available kinetic analysis is limited by mathematical approximations and human interpretation, here a deep neural network model has been trained to analyse ordinary kinetic data and automatically elucidate the corresponding mechanism class.

  • Jordi BurÃ©s
  • Igor Larrosa
Article 25 Jan 2023
